text:
ALAN GRODZINSKY: The
objective of the research

is looking at effects of
mechanical loading forces

on connective tissues,
like cartilage.
Very basic problem.

There are clinical
applications in diseases

such as osteoarthritis, some
second cousins to the processes

that go on in
rheumatoid arthritis,

and very fundamental biological
and bioengineering question

of how mechanical loading
forces affect living

cells in our tissues and can
make those tissues remodel,

degrade, or repair, depending
on the type of force that's
involved.

John's been studying how
mechanical forces affect

living tissues using
bovine knee joints.

John will cut the cartilage and
bone cores from the knee joint.

He'll then harvest the
cartilage and immediately

place them into a living
culture system in the incubator.

Then he'll take
pieces of cartilage

and put them in an
instrument to simulate

various mechanical loading
conditions of our joints,
like the knee joints.

Sometimes we walk,
sometimes we jump,

sometimes we're just
sitting or standing around.

We can simulate these
various mechanical conditions
to simulate a real injury.

And then, after the
mechanical loading is done,

he'll then go through
various measurements

of the biological
properties of the tissue.

He can look at gene
expression, taking the tissue,

freezing it under liquid
nitrogen conditions,

and then smashing the tissue
so that you can extract

the RNA, the molecule in
the cell that's telling us

how gene expression
is being affected

by these mechanical
loading forces.

There is an epidemic of knee
joint injuries happening

to high school and college
people, especially women

at much higher rates than men,
in which tears of ligaments

like the ACL or
tears of the meniscus

will ultimately lead
to osteoarthritis.

So one of the ongoing
objectives right now

in collaboration with the
pharmaceutical industry,

we're using our model system
as a drug discovery tool

because we can create an
injury in the incubator

without needing an
animal model yet.
It's an initial filter.

And we can follow the efficacy
of using certain drug compounds

to prevent or halt the
pathology that's induced
by this mechanical loading.

It's a problem that
is not just focused

in one aspect of
science or engineering.

In our own group, we have
students, undergraduates

and graduates in
mechanical engineering,

electrical engineering,
material science, physics, math,

chemical engineering, and
people that are hardcore cell
and molecular biology folks.

It's a very
multidisciplinary area.

And this is kind of a
hallmark of bioengineering
in general now.
